titleStmt.title: John Derricke's The Image of Irelande (1581): Plates
titleStmt.funder: Freedman Fellows Grant, Case West Reserve University

publicationStmt.authority: Dinah Mulock Craik: A Digital Archive

availability.p: Reproduced by courtesy of the REPOSITORY.
availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

msIdentifier.msName: The Image of Irelande, by John Derrick (London, 1581) - Plates

support.p: Some pages are torn and show signs of wear
Designed to be sold with, or bound to John Derricke's Image of Ireland

foliation.p: Numbers appear in the center of folio between verse columns.

origin.p: Believe to have been sketched in Ireland during Sir Henry Sidney's tenure as Lord Deputy of Ireland.

acquisition.p: The Edinburgh University Library copy of "The Image of Irelande, with a discouerie of VVoodkarne" was gifted by the poet William Drummond of Hawthornden, one of the early graduates of the Tounis College to his alma mater. The woodkarne, or woodkerne, were a semi-nomadic people, perceived as living by plunder and bloodshed like the Border Reivers in the Debatable Land between Scotland and England at the same period.

projectDesc.p: The project is to transcribe, encode, and publish, for the first time the full-text and plates of John Derricke's The Image of Irelande (1578)

correction.p: The transcription is based on two forms of a document. The base-text was a scan of the plates supplied by the University of Edinburgh Library. The initial transcriptions were made with the online images, but the final transcription was done with reference to the high-quality photos of the document.

As far as is possible, a diplomatic edition is intended, so there is a strong orientation towards the physical appearance of each page, including recording such aspects as indentations, centring, brackets, and spaces. All omissions, truncations, deletions, etc. in the original are retained. Text that is indecipherable is marked by the use of the <gap> element. The choice element, containing <orig> paired with <reg> marks text that is in some way possibly erroneous, idiosyncratic, or easily misunderstood with a clarification. Not marked are ligatures, dropped ‘r’, and long ‘s’.
Punctuation in the copy-text is retained.

normalization.p: Spelling is modernized. The transcription silently replaces the letters ‘u’ for ‘v’, ‘i’ for ‘j’, and ‘vv’ for ‘w’.

Abbreviations (eg. elided letters) and expansions (brevigraphs and contractions) are marked as such in both their contracted and expanded forms. Words, wordforms, or compounded words in which letters are elided by the scribe are designated as abbreviations and encoded with the element <abbr> and the attribute expan= recording both the construction of the original and the expanded format.

Marginal annotations included within the body of the text are distinguished from editorial annotations, which are encoded with the element <note> and the attribute type= with a description of ‘annotation’ to distinguish marginal from editorial notes, which are encoded with the element <note> and the attribute type= with a description of ‘editorial.’

Personal names of historical interest, mostly of poets or scribes, are identified as such and refer back to a <listPerson> item using a key tag. Within the listPerson descriptions, each person is identified with a ref pointer using the Library of Congress Authority number, and a second URI ref to the Dictionary of National Biography. Modern researchers or scholars who are referred to in the text, including the project team, are listed in a second listPerson element, with the attribute of type="modern".

The element <note> is used for additions to the text that are marginal and for editorial notes. They are delineated by first, type (editorial, annotation, marginal), and secondly, place on the page (in the case of a marginal note).

The element <gap> records the (possibly temporary) unavailability of a transcription, implying indecipherability, for one reason or another: faintness, obliteration (for example, by an ink blotch), deletion (when it so thorough that the deleted letters cannot be deciphered), invisibility (when the letters enter the spine of the book, erased, or torn. The extent of the indecipherable section is not recorded. The element <supplied> records instances in which a character is supplied by the editor on reasonable grounds that it exists. The element <unclear> is used to identify a transcription that is difficult to ascertain. The element “damage” is used for occasions where the text has suffered some damage, most usually due to ink blots. The element <space> is used to record deliberate gaps left by the scribes, with attribute of extent, with the value indicating the approximate number of characters or lines.

segmentation.p: In line with the orientation toward the physical aspect of the manuscript, graphical and bibliographical descriptions form an important component of the file. For example, we record details of page presentation, such as torn pages and a repaired leaf and we recognize of the former position of a page. Besides the description of such presentational aspects on a page as centring, indentation, brackets, and spaces is noted.

The text as a whole is divided into segments by the use of specialized element tags that record the division points that mark the boundaries between sections, known as milestone type element tags, with reference to the TEI Guidelines (6.9.3). For example, when the text is divided into columns, the point at which a new column begins is marked by a specialized element tag designed for that purpose (<cb/>), with an attribute value of left or right.

Despite recognizing divisions into pages, columns, and graphical lines, the principal orientation is into semantic units, poems, generally. The basic unit within the text of as a whole is the individual part or new page (<div>), together with its associated material, such as scribal annotations that appear in proximity to a poem and seem to refer to it. The poetic entity includes some units that are not strictly poems, such as poem fragments, anagram, annotation, figure, epigram, and some collective divisions (<ab> [anonymous block]) in which occur a number of what might be termed miscellaneous graffiti consisting of symbols, initials, words, epigrams, and drawings. Despite the varied nature of the basic division, it is here referred to as a poem.

The text of the poem itself is contained within a stanza division (or divisions, if there is more than one), using <lg> (linegroup). Each stanza is numbered sequentially within the poem (unless there is only one). The stanza divisions are according to standard indexes and modern editions (if there is such an edition) because scribal practice is highly variable in both the intention to divide the text into stanzas and the method of doing so. For instance, it is not assumed that scribes leave spaces between stanzas. Sometimes there is no indication as to where one stanza ends and another begins. Sometimes scribes indicate internal divisions with marks in the left margins, the use of majuscule characters, spaces between groupings, or by aligning the first line of a stanza to the left compared to the alignment of the other lines of that stanza. The existence and type of stanza marking (or lack thereof) are described in editorial notes. When a scribe’s presentation of stanzaic divisions differs from that given in standard indexes, the situation is recorded in an editorial note.

Each stanza is divided into poetic lines using <l> (poetic line), each of which is numbered sequentially within the poem in an attribute value n=. Lines that are aborted or deleted by a scribe but that are recognizably part of the poem are numbered with half-numbers that indicate their position in the sequence. Lines that are omitted (according to standard indexes and modern editions) are indicated by a row of hyphens, numbered and noted as omissions. Annotations are included as the content of an element <note> with an attribute type="annotation" to distinguish them from editorial notes that have an attribute type of "editorial" and scribal notes that have an attribute type="scribal". Annotations also have an attribute giving their place relative to the poem. Within annotations, if no line divisions are noted by the use of <seg>, it is to be assumed that the annotation is on one graphical line, unless it is marked as being placed 'inline.' The poetic lines are occasionally segmented to distinguish, for example, resonant phrases and graphically displaced words and phrases (as mentioned earlier). The element <w> (word) is occasionally used as an alternative when one word is involved in the distinction.

The encoding of witnesses follows the practice of the main text, however, the encoding is somewhat simplified. Only the relevant poems are included. Capitalization, abbreviations, deletions, and annotations are recorded. Each witness manuscript or print source is encoded in a single file, which validates to the DTD of the main document. Each witness file can be considered a satellite to the main document file.

The header section (which is also simplified) of each witness file includes an index encoded as a of incipits (as they appear in the witness text) arranged alphabetically within a

section within a that relates the location of a particular poem instance in the witness to the location within the Devonshire MS., which is repeated in the head section of each division. In addition, each relationship also mentions the other contemporary witnesses to that particular poem as a "See also" section and, when necessary, a designation of how that first line appears in the Devonshire MS, if there are significant differences. The header section includes a detailed description of the original source text used and, in some cases, also includes a description of the source of a modern transcription if that has been used instead, but it does not duplicate the detailed description of encoding practices as is found in the main document.

interpretation.p: Unless otherwise noted, responsiblity for all analytical or interpretive material that appears in the editorial notes rests with the editorial team as a whole.

div.head: A notable discovery most lively describing the state and condition of the WildeWild men in Ireland, properly called Woodkarne, with their actions, and exercises wherein they are daylydaily occupied, also the order of their relation and success of the same is likewise detected. Which also concludethconcludes with the commingcoming in of Thirlaugh Leonaugh the great ONEALE of Ireland, submitting himself to the right honorable SyrSir Henry Sydney, at what time he was L. Deputy general here of the saydsaid Land, being in An. 1578. Nowe published and set forth by JOHN DERRICK this present yeareyear of our Lord 1581. For pleasure and delight of those, whose mindesminds in laudable exercises are vertuouslyvirtuously occupied.

div.note: This line acts as an indicator Permission to print and distribute.

div.p: PilcrowAt London, printed by John Daye dwelling over Aldersgate1581

figure.figDesc: A soldier holding a battle-axe hands a spear to an Irish chieftain in full dress, with a page holding the chieftain's horse

div.l: The lively shape of Irysh Irish karne, most perfect to behold,
Of man, the master, and the boy, these pictures doedo unfoldeunfold:
Wherein is bravely payntedpainted forth, A naturallnatural Irish grace

Whose like in eu'ry every
poynt point to vewe view ,hath seldomeseldom stept stepped in place
Marke me the karne that gripesgrips the axe, fast with his murd'ring murdering hand
Then shalshall you say a righter knave, came never in the land:

p.note: Number "1" next to the column identifies this as plate 1

div.l: As for the rest so trimly drest dressed , I speake of them no evillevil,
In ech each respect, the are detect, (as honest as the devilldevil.)
As honest as the Pope himselfehimself, in all their outward actions,
And constant like the wavering windewind, in the Imaginations,
Which may be prov'de proved in sundry partes, hereafter that ensue,
A perfect signesign for to define, th'abovethe above additions true.

figure.figDesc: An armed company of the kerne, carrying halberds and pikes and led by a piper, attack and burn a farmhouse and drive off the horses and cattle

div.l: Here creepescreeps out of Sainct Fichers, a packepack of prowling mates,
Most hurtfullhurtful to the English pale, and noysome noisome to the states,
Which spare no more their country byrth birth , then those of th’englishthe English race,
But yeldyelled to each a lyke like good turneturn, when as they come in place.
They spoyle spoil and burneburn, and bearebear away, as fitte fit occasions serve,
And thinkethink the greater ill they doe do , the greater prayse praise deserve:

p.note: Number "2" next to the column identifies this as plate 2

div.l: They passe pass for the poorepoor mansman's cry, nor yet respect his tears,
But rather joy to see the fire, to flash about his earesears.

To see both flame, and smoldring smoldering smoke, to duskedusk the christall crystal
skyes skies ,
Next to their pray, therein I say, their second glory lyeslies.
And thus bereaving him of house, of cattell cattle and of store:
They do returnereturn backe back to the wood, from whence they came before.

figure.figDesc: The most famous plate of the set shows the chief of the Mac Sweynes seated at dinner and being entertained by a bard and a harper

div.l: Now when into their fenced holdes, the knaves are entred entered in
To smite and knockeknock the cattell cattle downedown, the hangmen doedo beginnebegin.
One plucketh off the Oxes Oxe's cotecoat, which he even now did wearewear:
Another lacking pannes pans , to boyleboil the flesh, his hide prepare.
These theeves thieves attend upon the fire, for serving up the feast:
And fryer frier smelfeastsmellfeast sneaking in, doth preace amongstamong the best.

p.note: Number "3" next to the column identifies this as plate 3

div.l: Who in Romish toyestoys the Ape, counterfettingcounterfeiting PaullPaul:
For they doedo award him then, the highest roomeroom of all.
Who set, because the cheerecheer, is deemed little worth:
Exce same be intermixtintermixed, and lac'delacked with Irish myrth.
Both and Harper, is preparde, which by their cunning art,
Doe and chearecheer up all the gestesguests, with comfort at the hartheart.

figure.figDesc: The Irish chieftain receives the priest's blessing before departing to fight the English, who are shown in full armour

div.l: And when with myrth and belly cheere cheer , they are sufficed well,
Mark what ensueth ensued , a playne plain discourse, of Irish sleightes slights I tell:
The fryer friar then absolves the theefe thief , from all his former sinne sin .

And bids him plague the princes prince's
frendes friends , if heaven he mindemind to winnewin.
Which beyng being saydsaid, he takes his horse, to put in practise practice then,

The spoyling spoiling and destroying of, her graces grace's
loyall loyal men.

metamark.note: Number "4" next to the column identifies this as plate 4

div.l:
But loe lo the souldiers soldiers then the plague, unto this Karnish
rowt route :
To yeld yield them vengaunce vengeance for their sinnes sins , in warlicke war like sort rise out.
They presse press the rauncoure rancour of the theeves thieves , by force of bloody knife.
And slay the pray they filcht filched away, depriving them of life:
The fryer friar then that traytrous traitorous knave, with Ough Ough hone lament:

To see his coosin cousin
Devills Devil's
sonnes sons , to have so fowle foul event.

figure.figDesc: The English soldiers return in triumph, carrying severed Irish heads and leading a captive by a halter

div.l:
And though the pray prey
recover'd recovered be, yet are not all thingesthings ended:

For why? the souldiours soldiers
doe do pursue, the Roges rogues that have offended,

Who never cease tilluntil in the bloud blood , of these light fing'red fingered
theeves thieves :
Their blades are bathd bathed to teach them how, they after prowle prowl for Beeves beefs .
To see a souldiour toze a Karne, O Lorde it is a wonder:

note.gloss: To pull asunder; to separate or unravel the fibresfibers of; to comb or card (OED.) Used here derisevely to point to the eminent beheading of a captive Irish soldier.

div.l: And eke also what care he takth takes to part, the head from neck a sonder asunder .

p.note: Number "5" next to the column identifies this as plate 5

div.l: To see another leade lead a theefe thief , with such a lordly grace:
And for to marke mark how lothe loath the knave, doth does follow in that case.
To see how trimmetrim their glibbed heades, are borneborn by valliantvaliant men,

And garded guarded with a royall royal
sorte sort , of worthy souldiours soldiers then.

All these are thinges things sufficient, to move a subjects subject's
minde mind :
To prayse praise the souldiours soldiers , which reward, the woodkarne in their kinde kind .

figure.figDesc: Sir Henry Sidney, Lord-Deputy, accompanied by an armed force, sets out from Dublin Castle for a progress through Ireland

div.l:
These trunckles trunckless
headdes heads do playnly plainly
showe show , eache each
rebeles rebel's
fatall fatal end,
And what a haynous heinous crime it is, the Queene Queen for to offend.
Although the theeves thieves are plagued thus, by Princes prince's trusty frends friends ,
And brought for their innormyties enormities , to sondrie sundry wretched endes ends :
Yet may not that a warning be, to those they leave behinde behind ,

But needes needs their treasons must appeare appear , long kept in festred festered
mynde mind .

Whereby the matter groweth growths at length, unto a bloudy bloody
fielde field ,

Even to the rebells rebels' overthrow, except the traytours traitors
yelde yield .

p.note: Number "6" next to the column identifies this as plate 6

div.l: for he that governesgoverns Irish soyle soil , presenting there her grace,
Whose fame made rebelles rebels often flye fly , the presence of his face:
He he I say, he goeth goes forth, with Marsis Mars' noble trayne train ,

To justifie justify his Princes Prince's cause, but their demenures demeanor's
vayne vain :
Thus Queene Queen he will have honored, in middest midst of all her foes,
And knowne known to be a royall royal Prince, even in despite of those.
